clinical_study.official_title: INTRAVENOUS KETAMINE IN TREATMENT-RESISTANT BIPOLAR DEPRESSION

collaborator.agency: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether a single intravenous administration of an N-methyl-D-aspartate antagonist is safe and effective for the acute treatment of bipolar depression.

detailed_description.textblock: Bipolar disorder (BPD) is a common, recurrent, and disabling medical condition. Although mania is the defining feature of BPD, depression represents the majority of illness burden in patients with this devastating condition. Despite the high degree of morbidity and mortality associated with bipolar depression, currently available treatments are few and often inadequate. Recently, a single intravenous (IV) dose of the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) glutamate receptor antagonist ketamine has demonstrated rapid antidepressant effects in severe unipolar depression. Therefore, the objective of the current study is to investigate the safety and efficacy of a single IV dose of ketamine in treatment-resistant bipolar depression (TRBD.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Change in available resources for study procedures

secondary_outcome.measure: Quick Inventory of Depressive Symptomatology, Self Report (QIDS-SR)
Systematic Assessment for Treatment Emergent Effects (SAFTEE)

intervention.description: participants in this group/condition receive a single IV infusion of ketamine, IV 0.5 mg/kg
participants in this group/condition receive a single IV infusion of midazolam, 0.025 mg/kg
